sentences.sentence: Canadian children have easy online access to globally divisive and offensive social and news media, and many opportunities to engage in it.
The opportunity to build online social capital and gain popularity can lead many children to engage in negative and offensive online communication and feel rewarded for this behaviour.

At the same time, social media also provides children and youth with access to positive communities and opportunities to engage in activist movements.Especially in a post-pandemic world, where the transition to online education and even more social interactions has meant youth spend even more of their time online, it is imperative for children and youth to be guided toward the best balance between free expression and offensive online expression.Children's negative interactions online are shaped by the physical and online adult world which normalizes high levels of online hate and violence.

Instead of focusing exclusively on the symptoms of bullying and cyberbullying, we must progress towards an examination of the roots of these actions.Online hate and harassment consists of three steps: dehumanization of targeted individuals and groups; ostracism from peer groups and communities; and, scapegoating of these individuals.

What few anti-bullying researchers have recognized is the similarities between these online behaviours that essentialize and marginalize some groups and individuals, and the role these same actions play in the extreme targeting of ethnic groups during wars, political upheavals, and ethnic cleansing.

Further, children and teens from marginalized backgrounds are at greater risk of being targeted online, with intersecting characteristics such as race, gender, sexual orientation, and disabilities among those features subjected to online discrimination.Canada's current legislation around cyberbullying is limited, especially when the case pertains to the actions of a minor under 18.

At the federal level, Bill C-13 (Protecting Canadians from Online Crime Act) criminalizes the publication of intimate images of a person without their prior consent.At the provincial level, the National Assembly of Quebec passed Bill-56 (An Act to Prevent and Stop Bullying and Violence in Schools) which stipulates that schools have an obligation to foster safe and healthy environments for youth which includes anti-bullying and anti-violence plans and procedures to report the use of online platforms for cyberbullying.

However, despite the well-intentioned goals of this legislation, critics point to the inability of the bill to ameliorate the root causes of cyberbullying.However, online communication provides children with opportunities to engage in activist and leadership movements and empower young people to take agency in addressing issues online as seen recently in the #MeToo and #BlackLivesMatter movements on social media platforms.
The decentralized nature of social media has allowed young people to self-organize, exchange knowledge and advocate more easily.

In this way, social media via peer interactions can empower young people to take agency in the issues they deem important to address.To amplify this positive potential, we propose critically, culturally, and legally informed multi-sectored partnership frameworks(https://www.mediatechdemocracy.com/work/defining-the-lines-with-impacts-a-multi-sectored-partnership-policymodel-to-rehumanize-childrens-online-communication-impacts-policy-model)grounded in student agency to guide children away from cyberbullying and towards ethical and inclusive online engagement.
Ultimately, no one stakeholder can adequately address the crisis of online bullying on their own.

It is essential for policy makers, educators and children to better understand and confront nuanced contextual realities of contemporary online communication and approach the issue of negative online interaction with constructive and informed discussions empowering a generation of young users and future leaders.Shaheen Shariff is James McGill Professor in the department integrated studies in education at McGill University.
Farah Stonebanks is a graduate student researcher.
